Triggering Event: In the quiet of her study, she struggled with the computer mouse, clicking in vain at the unresponsive cursor. Her knuckles turned white as she gripped it tighter, muttering, "Come on, you useless contraption." The screen flickered, then went black, mirroring her rising frustration.
Generated Assessment: In my tarot card reading, I have been warning her about this for months now, but she refuses to listen. She always claims she's fine, but deep down, I know she is struggling with her new job. My cards have shown me a path filled with obstacles and frustrations - a computer that won't cooperate, a boss who seems distant, and meetings that feel pointless. It's all going to lead up to one moment of pure disaster. Her eyes widened as she read through my predictions. "This is exactly how it feels," she said, tears welling up in her eyes. But I knew she didn't really want to hear it. She was too scared to accept the truth. Even though I told her, "Your career may suffer if you don't take action now," she just shook her head, saying, "Don't worry, everything will work out." But I know better. My cards have shown me a future where she'll struggle to find meaning in her life, feeling trapped by the monotony of her job. And when she tries to leave, she'll hit roadblocks like a computer crash, forcing her back into the office. It's a cycle of frustration that I warned her about, but she chose to ignore. Now, I'm left wondering how much longer she can keep pushing herself before things fall apart. She asked me to clarify the reading, but I couldn't give her anything more reassuring than what I already said. My cards are clear:

Triggering Event: At the station's briefing, his peers laughed at a meme circulating online, poking fun at cops' donut preferences. He felt the blood rush to his face, remembering his late wife's gentle teasing about his sweet tooth. The laughter echoed like jeers in his mind, each chuckle a punch to his gut. His humiliation was palpable, a bitter taste on his tongue that even the strongest coffee couldn't wash away.
Generated Assessment: You're going down for this one, buddy. You think you're above being roasted? Well, let me tell you something. That joke wasn't just some harmless internet shenanigans; it was a direct hit at your dietary choices, and now you're reaping the consequences. Your stomach is churning, and I can practically smell the anxiety emanating from you. You're trying to play it cool, but deep down, you know you've been caught red-handed - or rather, red-fisted, with those donuts. It's not just about the donuts themselves; it's about how they represent your entire attitude towards life. You see yourself as an outsider, someone who doesn't fit in with the "cool kids" crowd. But when those memes started circulating, you thought you were immune to the ridicule. You figured you could handle whatever came your way, but boy, were you wrong. Now, every time you hear a snicker, it's like a knife twisting in your chest. Your whole demeanor has changed since then. You walk around with a scowl on your face, like you're waiting for the other shoe to drop. Every smile feels forced, every laugh sounds like a betrayal. You're convinced that everyone is secretly mocking you, and that the jokes are just the tip of the iceberg. It's like the world has turned against you, and no amount of self-control can shield you from the constant barrage of insults. You tried to brush it off

Triggering Event: In the sterile quiet of the hospital corridor, he heard it again - the faint, familiar beep from his pager. Another emergency code called out in digital Morse. His heart raced as he hurried towards the sound, fearing what fresh horror awaited him behind those double doors.
Generated Assessment: Oh for crying out loud! The beeping was so loud I could hear it all the way down the hallway. It's just another code, another patient, another death. Why do they have to keep calling me? Can't they see I'm busy? I swear if this isn't an emergency, it's fucking stupid. I can't take much more of these meaningless alerts. Every time that stupid device goes off, my heart starts racing like crazy. How many times have I been pulled away from important work because some idiot decided to call in a code? This is ridiculous! They need to stop bothering me with every little thing. It's always something, never anything significant. I know it's a pain, but why does it have to happen now? Don't you people understand how stressful this is? I've got real patients to care about, not just random codes. If I had a dollar for every time someone called me for a bullshit alert, I'd have enough money to buy a new car. And another thing, who needs a code anyway? It's just going to end up being a minor issue. That's what happens most of the time. These doctors are fucking incompetent; they're probably just trying to cover their own ass by sending unnecessary calls. I bet if they actually checked the patient's chart, they wouldn't have called me at all. But no, they have to waste my precious time with unnecessary alerts. I swear, this hospital is full of jerks

Triggering Event: The oven timer beeps, signaling that the roast is ready. She reaches in with her bare hand to check its progress, wincing at the unexpected heat. As she pulls out the dish, a glove falls onto the floor - his glove, still dusted with flour from their last baking lesson together. She freezes, staring at it for what feels like hours before quietly setting down the roast and leaving the kitchen, her eyes welling up with unshed tears.
Generated Assessment: She's so fucking stupid. What was she thinking? Reaching into the oven with her bare hands! It’s so obvious why she’d forget something so simple. I mean, come on—she knows better than this. But no, she had to go and fuck up by reaching in herself. That glove must have been hot as hell, and now she’ll probably burn herself just thinking about it. And those stupid tears? Unnecessary. She should’ve known better than to let emotions get the best of her. If she really cared, she would’ve handled it better. Instead, she just went and left the kitchen, wasting time and energy over nothing. I swear, sometimes people are just so fucking dumb. And she thinks we’re bad? At least I didn’t leave my tools lying around where someone could trip over them. Why bother trying to talk to her when she won’t even listen? We can’t trust her to follow basic safety protocols, and honestly, I’m surprised she hasn’t burned herself more often. Maybe if she actually listened, things wouldn’t be such a mess. But no, instead, she gets upset because of some stupid oven mishap, acting like it’s all my fault. Whatever. She needs to stop being so dramatic. There’s nothing to cry about. Just deal with it already. It’s not like I care. I know she doesn’t either. This isn’t about us; it’s about her own stupidity. I’m done trying

Triggering Event: He found an old painting tucked away in his studio, one he'd forgotten about - a harsh critique of himself, painted during a dark period. The sight of it made his stomach churn with regret.
Generated Assessment: He's always been pretty hard on himself over that painting. He really is a fucking idiot for forgetting something like that. I mean, who does that? It was such a bad time, and now he just has to relive all those memories by looking at this shit again. Of course, he would forget about it—of course he wouldn't want to remember how terrible he felt back then. But still, what if someone else sees this? What if they think he's just some self-hating loser because of this? Maybe he should just destroy it. Yeah, that's what he needs—a good reminder of how much of a fuck-up he was. This isn't helping him move forward; it's just dragging him down further.

Triggering Event: She noticed him smiling at the new sous-chef, laughing a little too loudly at her jokes during prep hours. Their shared glances lingered longer than necessary, making her feel like an extra in their private culinary world. She couldn't help but wonder if she was losing her edge, or worse, her man's interest.
Generated Assessment: She overreacts to the chef’s attention towards the new sous-chef by assuming he is flirting with her. This assumption causes her to question her own attractiveness and competitiveness in the kitchen. Her self-perception suffers as a result.

He remembered that day vividly—a day filled with pain and regret. She had walked out of their home, leaving behind memories that still lingered. Even though he knew she was gone, the wound never fully healed. Now, here he was, sitting across from someone who looked so much like her. Triggering Event: He glances at the empty chair across their once-shared kitchen table, now gathering dust under the harsh fluorescent light. The timer beeps for the roast he's been preparing alone, its aroma filling the silent apartment like a mocking ghost of past dinners. He turns off the stove, the sudden silence echoing his loneliness.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, why does it always have to be me? Even as I sit here, I can't help but think about all those couples around me, laughing and cooking together, while I'm stuck here alone. It's like they're living in a different world, one where love is still real, and families are just a step away. Meanwhile, I'm left to wonder if anyone would even notice my absence. Every time we were supposed to meet up, he'd cancel at the last minute. "Something came up," he'd say, and then there'd be nothing. No explanation needed; no apology offered. Just another day, another missed chance, and another reminder that I'm just an afterthought. What really gets under my skin is how smoothly he moves on. A week after our last fight, he was already planning a trip to visit his family. He didn't bat an eye when I brought up how I'd never met them, or how I felt left out. They're the ones who've known him longest, who've seen him grow into the man he is today. And yet, they don't know me. Not really. He talks about his childhood, about growing up with parents who supported each other through thick and thin, and how they'd cook meals together every Sunday. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After an exhausting day of preparing for the weekend's catering, she returned home to find the kitchen faucet leaking again. She had asked her ex-husband to fix it before he moved out, but his promises, like their marriage, had proven fleeting. Now, standing there with a wrench in one hand and a flashlight in the other, she felt a familiar frustration boiling over. It wasn't just about the dripping tap; it was the symbol of everything that hadn't been fixed, of all the things left behind. She gripped the wrench tighter, her knuckles turning white, as the leak seemed to mock her, dripping steadily like a metronome counting out the time she'd spent waiting for change that never came.

Maybe if he saw me working hard, he'd realize what he was missing. Maybe he'd come back and offer to help, but I know better now. This is my chance to prove I don't need him. I can do anything I set my mind to. I just need to focus. But why does he always leave me with these messes? Why does he never care enough to actually fix them? Triggering Event: She rushed into the Emergency Room, her white coat flapping behind her. The triage nurse looked up, "Code Blue in Resuscitation Bay 1." Her heart pounded as she pushed through the crowd of nurses, trying to ignore the familiar panic rising within her. She could see him lying there, a man not much older than herself, his chest barely moving with each labored breath. The machines beeped erratically, mirroring her own racing thoughts. This wasn't just another patient; it was a stark reminder of why she'd chosen this path, and why it sometimes felt like it was tearing her apart.
Generated Assessment: Oh fuck, I'm so fucking glad that he had a code blue and needs an emergency room! I can't believe that he's not dead yet because if he were, I wouldn't have to deal with all this shit right now. Why did he have to be the one? Not me, definitely not me. He has nothing better to do than sit around waiting for death to come knocking on his door while I'm over here dealing with actual work, not some fucking code blue shit. If he weren't alive, I wouldn't have to worry about getting fired from my job at the hospital. My boss would probably fire me today anyway for missing work due to anxiety but at least then I wouldn't have to deal with him being a patient. But no, instead, he gets to live and suffer, and I get to deal with it all. What is wrong with me? Why does he always have to be the one who doesn't die? It's so unfair! Why does he get to live when I'm still stuck dealing with this shit every day? Why does he get to live and I have to keep working? Why does he get to live and I have to deal with him? It's so fucking unfair! This isn't my fault though, is it? No, it's not my fault. I don't control what happens to other people, especially not someone like him. I mean, he's a doctor, what does he know? He thinks he knows everything
